security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The hardcoded URL is metadata, backticks in documentation are for command examples, and 'weak cryptographic algorithm' alerts are misidentified JSON structures. The external_commands risk factor is expected for a linting skill that runs the linters tool.

content.value_statement: Manual linting after code changes is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill automates running linters by auto-detecting active linters in the repository and executing them with proper configurations.
actual_capabilities: Auto-detects active linters in the current repository
Analyzes linting results and identifies issues
Iteratively fixes linting issues until all are resolved
limitations: Cannot run linters that are not already installed in the repository
Cannot modify linter configurations - only reports issues
Does not run after each edit - requires manual invocation
Cannot skip specific linting rules without user approval

use_cases.title: Pre-commit Code Quality Check
use_cases.description: Run linters before creating a commit or pull request to ensure code meets quality standards and passes CI checks.

use_cases.title: Post-refactoring Verification
use_cases.description: After making code changes, run linters to catch and fix any style or quality issues introduced during the refactor.

use_cases.title: Codebase Cleanup Session
use_cases.description: Systematically run and fix linter issues across multiple files to improve overall code quality and consistency.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Lint Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Run linters to check the code quality of my changes.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to verify code quality after making changes

prompt_templates.title: Pre-commit Quality Gate
prompt_templates.prompt: Run linters on all modified files and fix any issues found. Report back when all linting errors are resolved.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to ensure code passes quality checks before committing

prompt_templates.title: Full Repository Lint
prompt_templates.prompt: Run linters on the entire repository. Start with the most critical issues and work through them systematically until the codebase is lint-clean.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to address accumulated linting debt

prompt_templates.title: Incremental Quality Improvement
prompt_templates.prompt: Run linters and create a summary of all issues found. For each issue, read the file, understand the error, fix it, and re-run linters to verify. Continue until all issues are resolved.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants thorough fixing of all linting problems with context-aware fixes

best_practices: Run linters after completing a logical set of changes, not after each small edit
Fix all reported issues before marking the task complete
Ask the user before disabling or modifying linting rules
anti_patterns: Running linters after every single line change - wastes time and interrupts flow
Ignoring linting errors without understanding them
Disabling linting rules without consulting the team

faq.question: What linters does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill auto-detects installed linters in your repository. Common linters like ESLint, Prettier, RuboCop, Pylint, and shellcheck are supported.

faq.question: Can I skip certain linting rules?
faq.answer: The skill will not skip rules without your approval. Ask the user before disabling any linting rule.

faq.question: Does this modify my linter configuration files?
faq.answer: No. The skill only runs linters and uses the Edit tool to fix code issues. It does not change configuration files.

faq.question: What happens if a linter is not installed?
faq.answer: The skill reports that the linter was not found and continues with other detected linters.

faq.question: Can I run linters on specific files only?
faq.answer: The skill runs all detected linters. The linters themselves may operate on changed files or the entire project depending on configuration.

faq.question: How long does linting typically take?
faq.answer: Execution time depends on repository size and number of linters. Small projects take seconds; large codebases may take a minute or more.
